description:
Vitis riparia x Vitis rupestris is a hybrid grape species that combines the genetic characteristics of two distinct wild grape species, Vitis riparia and Vitis rupestris.

Vitis riparia, commonly known as the riverbank grape or frost grape, is a North American species native to the central and eastern regions of the United States and Canada. It is known for its tolerance to cold temperatures and resistance to certain grape diseases.

Vitis rupestris, also called the sand grape or sugar grape, is another North American wild grape species that is adapted to grow in rocky, well-drained soils and has a high level of resistance to phylloxera, a devastating grape pest.

The hybrid Vitis riparia x Vitis rupestris combines the advantageous traits of both parent species, such as cold hardiness, disease resistance, and the ability to grow in challenging soil conditions. This hybrid is often used as a rootstock for commercial grape cultivation, providing a hardy and resilient foundation for the grafting of desired grape cultivars.

The resulting hybrid exhibits characteristics intermediate between the two parent species, with a unique combination of leaf shape, fruit characteristics, and overall vigor and adaptability. This hybrid has played an important role in the development of modern viticulture, helping to expand the range and resilience of cultivated grape varieties.
